title: Dexus puts last Canberra asset on the chopping block
text:
An Canberra office building is the latest on Dexus' chopping block as the ASX-listed property group focuses on divesting its "non-core assets" so as to recycle capital into other buoyant CBD markets.

It is understood Dexus is close to appointing agents to sell Garema Court, an A-grade office property at 140-180 City Walk, which is in a prime position in Canberra's Civic precinct. The property is expected to reap about $75 million, above its latest book value of $71.5 million.

Dexus plans to sell its last Canberra asset.

The building's major tenant is the Commonwealth of Australia. It has 10,883sq m of office space, ground-floor retail space and 68 car parks.

It is the last Canberra asset left in the group's portfolio, following the divestment this year of the Finlay Crisp complex – three adjacent buildings on the southern edge of Civic – which sold to Singapore-based investment firm SC Capital Partners for $62 million.

Dexus also offloaded a group of Macquarie Park buildings in Sydney that were also deemed "non-core" to Goodman, in a deal worth $231.2 million.
description: The ASX-listed property group is focusing on divesting its "non-core assets".
